description:
Learning objectives: 

  • Interact with other students while trying to resolve a programming problem.
  • Experience change in requirements
  • Report orally on progress made in a team
  • Submit a single report in Canvas for a group

Part 1 - Group Work  
approximately 45 minutes. 

Problem: 

Write a program that analyzes numbers in a given range (1 to 100 by default, randomize them (atleast 20) and performs the following tasks:

1. Identify and print all even numbers.

2. Identify and print all odd numbers.

3. Calculate and display the sum of all numbers.

4. Find and display the largest prime number in the range.

 

For this first assignment, the TA will describe the work to be done in person during the lab. The TA will determine the teams. You can choose to use any tool/language you want, but each student must participate and write code.  

What to submit:

  • Submit screenshots of the chosen problem and your progress in solving it. 
  • One submission for the team in Canvas (with the name of teammates on the submission).
  • Notice the due date for this submission is before the end of the lab!  


Part II - Group Demo

To receive a grade, you will need to do a group demo (approximately 10 minutes) demonstrating what you have accomplished and the challenges you have encountered. 

 

Part III - Start working on the next assignment

For the rest of the lab, you can start working on the individual assignment due before the beginning of the next lab.  Link to assignment: A tool for source code management
name: Timeboxed Coding

description:
Follow the instructions in the two parts of the following git homework: 

  • GitHW1.docx
  • GitHW2.docx
  • Lab - 1 Setting up Git.pptx

 

What to submit?

Submit a single PDF file that contains the following:

  1. The link to the forked repository on Canvas which should have your new merged into master. Do not delete this branch after it is merged.
  2. The requested screenshots.
name: A tool for source code management

description:
PayStation TDD

Learning objectives: 

  • Write simple Java code.
  • Edit, compile, and run JUnit Java code without a Main function.
  • Practice Test Driven Development.
  • Demonstrate the ability to exchange code with a partner using a version control system.  

 

Part I - Team Assignment

  • Do this assignment in a team of three students (not the same person as in your team of two from the first lab). Ask your TA for the team assignment. 
  • Each team member has to accept the assignment in GitHub Classroom. This will automatically clone/fork  a private team repository on GitHub for your assignment (and add TAs as owners) Use this link: https://classroom.github.com/a/_gomPZDC
  • The first team member will have to create a team and give it a name.  Use this format for the name of the team: "04 Hospet-Shrivastava  Awesome Owl Team"  Where 04: (01 to 05, your section number) Hospet-Shrivastava-Paoli: (family names of your team members),  Awesome Owl Team (anything you want to call your team or nothing). 
    • The second and third team members will join that team.
    • Any new member will either join an existing team or create a new team.
    • Please make sure you join the correct team.
    • At this point, you should have a private GitHub repository for the team. The repository will contain the starter code.

 

Part  II - Coding

Follow the recommendations of your TA for which Java IDE to use. Then use git on the command line or GitHub Desktop to clone the paystation git repository you created in Part I in your local workspace.

Get more information about the project here: PayStation.pdf

Coding Requirements: Make the following modifications to the PayStation:

  • All development should follow TDD.  Commit to the repository after each test is added and when each test passes. Alternate team members between each task, this should be visible in the git commit log. (This is one important goal of this assignment!  Many points will be deduced if the git commit log does not show alternating contributions from each team member.)

  • Add a method int empty() that returns the total amount of money collected by the PayStation since the last call and empties it, setting the total to zero. Note that money is only collected after a call to buy.
  • Change the requirements for (cancel) to the following:
/** Cancel the present transaction. Resets the paystation for a 
* new transaction. 
* @return A Map defining the coins returned to the user. 
* The key is the coin type and the associated value is the 
* number of these coins that are returned. 
* The Map object is never null even if no coins are returned. 
* The Map will only contain only keys for coins to be returned. (If you enter two dimes and a nickle, you should get back two dimes and a nickle, not a quarter.)
* The Map will be cleared after a cancel or buy. 
*/
 
Map<Integer, Integer> cancel();
  • There should be the following test cases:
    • Call to empty returns the total amount entered.
    • Canceled entry does not add to the amount returned by empty.
    • Call to empty resets the total to zero.
    • Call to cancel returns a map containing one coin entered.
    • Call to cancel returns a map containing a mixture of coins entered. ( Entering 10c, 10c and 5c then pressing cancel is returning 2x10c and 1x5c and really not returning 1x25c)
    • Call to cancel returns a map that does not contain a key for a coin not entered.
    • Call to cancel clears the map.
    • Call to buy clears the map.
  • All team members should participate in coding. (Visible by commit author)

 

Part III - Writing

  1. Commit messages: All commits should include a descriptive and sensible commit comment.  This is visible in the GitHub commit log. 

2.  Complete individually PayStationTDD Individual Report

 

What to submit?

  • For this assignment submit a link to your GitHub repository. Don't forget also to submit the individual report.   

 

Part IV - Demo

You need to do a group demo of your work to your TA to receive a grade.
name: PayStation TDD (Due week 3)

description:
Testing Report

After having completed PayStation TDD, submit your Individual Report. 

You can use this template Link that includes all the following parts:

    • Title Page: Showing the name of the document, authors, URL of the git repository, course, and section number. 

    • Document Overview: Summarize the purpose and contents of the document. The Test Report is a record that the tests were run and a documentation of their results. 

    • Test Report Narrative: At least two paragraphs of text describing the testing done.
      • Explain in your own words what were the requirements for this work.
      • Did you implement everything that was asked?
      • Did you make additional improvements?
      • Describe any known problems you encountered.
      • Describe any test in failed status. Explain what tests are missing if any.
      • If more testing was required what kind of test you would propose? (if any tests are failing or missing, explanations are mandatory).  
    • Appendix:
      • Copy of the output from the unit test runs. The status of each individual test should be visible.   (In InteliJ:  Export test results to a fileLinks to an external site., open html report in a browser and print to a pdf or copy paste in a Word document) 
      • Copy of the output of the coverage report. The coverage of each source file should be visible.  (In InteliJ:  Save coverage data to a fileLinks to an external site., open html report in a browser and print to a pdf or copy paste in a Word document)
name: PayStation TDD Individual Report (Due week 3)

description:
Part I - Team assignment

  • Do this assignment in teams of two or three students as designated by your TA. 
  • Each team member has to accept the assignment in GitHub Classroom. The first team member will have to create a team that will be joined by the second team member. Use this link: https://classroom.github.com/a/a-TxZRNX 
  • Register your team with the TA to create the same team in Canvas and setup and appointment to do the demo of your work on the due date. 
  • Protect the “main” branch, as explained in the second part of Lab 2 - A tool for source code management.  Apply the protection to the branch 'main' (not 'master'). In branch settings activate: 
    1. Go To Repository Settings  2) Select "Branches"  3) Click "Add classic branch protection rule"'
    2. Enter "main" for  Branch name pattern.  
    3. Click "Require a pull request before merging".  Commits must be made to a branch and submitted via a pull request before they can be merged.
    4. Click "Do not allow bypassing the above settings". The above settings will apply to administrators.
  • Code will need to be first developed on a working branch. You’ll have to then create a pull request and have your code reviewed by another team member. 

 

Part  II - Coding

Now that you have the JAVA class source code to implement the PayStation application. Each class has been tested using the JUnit testing tool. Now you’ll put all the pieces together to complete a final product. In this lab assignment, you are required to develop a main program to demo to the clients how the product works.

A main() program should be developed to simulate the PayStation operation. It displays a menu to allow a customer to select a choice:

  • Deposit Coins
  • Display
  • Buy Ticket
  • Cancel
  • Empty (Admin)
  • Change Rate Strategy (Admin)

A maintenance worker may select the Admin menu options to empty the PayStation or Change Rate Strategy while the PayStation system is running. When Change Rate Strategy is chosen, a submenu will show different city names with their respective rate strategies. 

The simulation software should show the following features:

  • accept coins for payment.
    • 5, 10, 25 cents
  • show time bought on display.
  • when a parking ticket is bought, prints a receipt with parking time.
  • when a transaction is canceled, prints the returned coins’ values and number of each coin type.
  • Implement rate strategies for five clients:
    • Linear1 rate for Alphatown (5c buys two minutes)
    • Progressive rate for Betatown (see below)
    • Alternating1 rate for Gammatown (weekdays:progressive + weekend:linear1 ).
    • Linear2 rate for Deltatown (5c buy 1 minute)
    • Alternating2 rate for Omegatown (weekdays:linear1 + weekend:free).
  • Rate strategy selections and changes can be done on the fly, i.e. at run-time. The default rate strategy is linear1 (Alphatown) rate.
  • Alternating rate is a hybrid rate depending on the day of the week. Linear1 rate applies on weekends and progressive rate applies on weekdays.
    • To get extra credit:  account for weekend rollover (if a user enters coins at 11:30pm on Sunday, the first 30 minutes use linear rate, and any further coins use progressive rate).  Don’t worry about splitting coins (quarter entered at 11:55pm can give 10 minutes according to linear rate).
    • Java’s Calendar class provides a good starting point for this requirement.
    • Calendar’s set() will be helpful for testing purposes.

See class material for requirements for linear and progressive rates.  Requirements Variants.pptx

  • Summary: 
/* Linear1 Rate Strategy */
time = (amount * 2) / 5;

/* Progressive Rate Strategy */
/* less than an hour (60 Min) so amount <150 */
time = (amount * 2) / 5;
/* between 1st hour and 2nd hour so 350>amount >=150 */
time = (amount - 150) * (3 / 10) + 60;
/* greater than 2 hours so amount >= 350 */
time = (amount - 350) / 5 + 120;

/* Alternating1 Rate Strategy */
/* On Weekdays Uses Progressive Rate  */
/* On Weekends Uses Linear1 Rate Strategy */

/* Linear2 Rate Strategy */
time = amount / 5;

/* Alternating2 Rate Strategy */
/* On Weekdays Uses Linear1 Rate  */
/* On Weekends Free */

Part III - Writing

  1. Source code management
    • All commits should have a commit message.
    • All pull requests should have a code review message.
  2. Design Document: You can use this template that includes all the following parts: 
    • Title Page: showing the name of the document, authors, URL of the git repository, course, and section number. 
    • Document Overview: summarize the purpose and contents of the document. 
    • Achitecture. Produce a UML class diagram to visualize the new architecture of the PayStation. Add text to explain the relationship between the class. Imagine that the reader does not understand UML well and explain what is represented on the diagram. 
    • Detailed Design API. Describe details about all methods and classes of the architecture. 
    • You can use this template: DesignReportTemplate_3296S25_220124.docx

What to submit?
In Canvas submit a PDF document of your Design Report.  The cover page needs to have a link to your git repository.   The grade will only be assigned to all team members after the demo.  

Part IV - Demo 

To receive a grade you need to do a demo of your work to your TA.
name: PayStationMain: main program and rate strategies - (Due Week 5)

rubric.long_description: Demonstration is professional. All team members are present. All team members are knowledgeable of all parts of the assignment and can answer questions about it.
UML accurately represents implemented solution. Relationship are explained in text.  Writing is professional.

All technical requirements are fulfilled: Each rate strategy is properly implemented and the user is able to switch between them at run-time (2.0 pts). All menu options are functional (1.0 pt). All program output is formatted sensibly (1.0 pt). Code is readable, well-commented, and resembles industry-standard Java style.

Some thorough testing scheme was developed and implemented on the project.  Tests are relevant to the final code-base. If using automated testing: automated tests are correct and follow code conventions. If using manual testing: good record of tests are kept.

What to submit?

  • At least two Pull Request that are merged in the Github repository.

description:
Objective:

  • Draw a UML class diagram (Use any tool you prefer  https://www.draw.io/  or https://mermaid.js.org/intro/ are a free suggestions).  

 

UML example for PayStationTDD

 

What to submit?

  • The first part of the Design Document with the Architecture 
    • A complete UML Class Diagram for the full project even if the code is not written yet. You will be allowed to update the diagram for the final submission.  
    • Do not forget to represent the Main() method so we can identify in which class it is located. 
    • You can use use this document at a template: DesignReportTemplate_3296S25_220124-1.docx
name: PayStationMain: Individual one week review - (Due Week 4)

description:
Part I - Team assignment  - (due before end of first lab)

  • Do this 2-week assignment in team of two or three students. 
    • First team member: create a team:  https://classroom.github.com/a/hCFN4BfM and give it a name.  Use this format: "04 Hospet-Shrivastava  Awesome Owl Team"  Where 06: (01 to 04, your section number) Hospet-Shrivastava: (family names),  Awesome Owl Team (team name). 
    • The second team member joins the team.
  • Setup a project board to track your team's progress.
    • Create a project board with three columns.  In Github, select the Project tab and create a new project with three columns (Todo, In Progress, Done).  Alternatively, your TA could instruct you to use Trello it JIRA.
    • Add  tasks from below in the Todo column.  You can add more tasks you want to track like updates to the report. 
    • When a task is moved to In Progress (or Done) make sure it is assigned to the person who is doing the work. 

Part  II - Coding

Each task has to be implemented in a different pull request.

Update your project board while working on the assignment.  Drag tasks from the To Do column to the column In Progress or Done accordingly.  

The purpose of this lab assignment is to observe and resolve the race condition in a multi-thread program. You are given the initial source code of a bank fund transferring simulation program as described in the class. The initial program does not have any means to protect the critical part of the code to prevent race condition. So race condition always happens when it runs. Here are the tasks you have to do (in that order) and their requirements.

 

Task 1. Run the initial program as is to observe the race condition and explain how the race condition may occur.

You can force the race condition to be more apparent by uncommenting the Thread.yield() statements in the Account class.

Task 2. Implement protection code to resolve the race condition issue.  Your solution must allow the bank to transfer multiple funds between unrelated accounts, e.g. from account [2] to account [5] and from account [3] to account [7] at the same time.  You may use either synchronized object locks or classes implementing the Lock interface to prevent two transferring threads from accessing the same global variables simultaneously.

In addition to testing the bank at the end of all the transfers, we also want to test it periodically. Uncomment the line in Bank.transfer that reads: if (shouldTest()) test();

Run the program again and you will notice now that the test method reports an error again. This is because while the test method is summing the amounts in each account in one thread, transfers are still taking place in other threads. This is the source of another race condition.  In the next tasks we will fix this.

Task 3. Refactor the method of testing into a new separate thread.

Task 4. Provide code protection so that the newly-created testing thread and any other transfer threads are running exclusively.

Now we have protected the critical sections of the code by providing mutual exclusion between the testing thread and the transfer threads.  But we want to run the test at regular intervals, so we need a solution to guarantee that the test runs at the right time.

Task 5. Implement a wait/signal solution for the testing thread and transfer threads, i.e. the testing thread starts with a signal to all transferring threads, waits for all the transferring threads to finish the current transfer, and then takes over the testing task while all the transferring threads are waiting until the test is done.

Task 6. The initial code does not allow an account to transfer out funds if the transferring amount is greater than the account balance. Implement a wait/notify solution to defer the transfer until the account balance becomes greater than the transferring amount (assume the account will receive the funds later).

Task 7. Deadlock condition may occur if one thread finishes all the funds transfers and exits. Implement a solution in which all threads stop transferring (the bank is closed) whenever one thread completes its transfers. This will solve the deadlock issue.

Note that solutions that do not permit unrelated transfers to take place simultaneously are not acceptable.

 

Part III - Writing

Design document following the same template as previous report: 

  • Explain in your own words what were the requirements for this work?  Did you implement everything that was asked? For each of the tasks, explain what was implemented. 
  • UML Class Diagram. 
  • First UML Sequence Diagram illustrating the race condition in the initial version of BankSim program .
  • Second UML Sequence Diagram illustrate how the test() method call is invoked after Task 3. 
    • For each UML diagram add a paragraph of text explaining what is represented on the diagram. 

What to submit?

  • A Design Document including:
    • Names of all team members 
    • Link to the Git repo
    • Link to the project board 
    • UML diagrams and required text

Only one submission for the team is necessary,. The grade will be assigned to all team members after the demo.  

Part IV - Demo 

To receive a grade you need to do a demo of your work to your TA.
name: BankSim: Multi-thread program - (Due Week 7)

rubric.long_description: Demonstration is professional. All team members are presents. All team members are knowledgeable of all parts of the assignment and can answer questions about it.
Writing is professional. Syntax and grammar are respected. All questions are answered. Diagrams follow UML conventions.
Code is professional. Code follow usual coding conventions. Assignment is meeting all requirements from the problem statement.
Code is in a git repository. Latest version of code is in git. Code is working first time without needing ajustements or modifications.

description:
Learning Objectives

  • Review initial progress for BankSim: Multi-thread program - (Due Week 7)

Demo

  • The Git repository is created. 
  • A project board is created.
    • All required tasks are created.  
    • Tasks are in the appropriate column according to their current completion status. 
    • Tasks in the InProgress or Done column should be identified with the person who has done the work. 
  • Task 1, 2, and 3 should be Done with a pull request merged to main. 
  • Task 4 should be (at least) In Progress.
  • Explain your UML Sequence Diagram and where the race condition occurs

What to submit?

  • A Design Document including:
    • Link to the Git repo
    • Link to the project board 
    • UML Class Diagram
    • UML Sequence Diagram illustrating the race condition in the initial version of BankSim program.
name: BankSim: Individual one week review - (Due Week 6)

name: Final Project Proposal Submission

description:
Length: 2 to 5 min

When: 1st half of the lab

What to present:  

This presentation can be done by using the whiteboard only in front of the class or using a maximum of one PowerPoint slide.

  • Don't forget to say your name and write your name on the slide or whiteboard,
  • Say the project name and write down your project title too.
  • What the project is about, the main goal? Add details on the slide including the programming language and architecture. 
  • What the code contribution would be? What competencies or interests would be needed from other team members?
  • Run your proof of concept.
  • You should be out of time by now. 

What to submit

  • Upload a single-page PowerPoint or PDF you will use to present (optional or use the whiteboard)
  • Create a new issue in the following repo with your subject proposal. Access the repo using the following link: https://classroom.github.com/a/8Jicvsgm (Do NOT create a new team! Select the appropriate team that has already been created for your section).
  •  In the issue you are creating include:
    1. A relevant title.
    2. The full text of your project proposal in the body of the issue created (don't just put a link to a word document elsewhere). 
    3. A link to your Proof of Feasibility.
    4. The slide from this whiteboard presentation (or a photo of the whiteboard).
    5. Assign appropriate labels to your new issue.
name: Project Proposal Presentation

description:
Please fill in this survey so we can group you. Even if you did not give your presentation fill the form, or you will not be grouped with anyone for the project 

 

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe-VCu1_lRbGkzUEwM1bFIstTHAjt4pFQffJZVSzCAFd-rGcQ/viewform?usp=sharing
name: Project group formation survey

description:
Part I - Team assignment (first day)

  • Accept the assignment in GitHub Classroom to create your team repo. The first team member will have to create a team that the other team member will join. Use this link: https://classroom.github.com/a/N0F8JA9S 
  •  Your team name should follow this format: "05-Awesome Team Name" where 05 is your section number followed by your team name, no need to include the members' last names.  
  • Attention: this repository is public! Your GitHub ID and contributions will be visible on the Internet.  If you prefer more anonymity,  you can join this repository with an alternative Github account but must inform your TA and professor. 
  • Recommended: Rename your repository. Because we are using Github Classroom the repository created are all starting with the prefix "prj-". As this repo is public, you may want to rename it to something nicer before using it and sharing it.  Instructions are here: Renaming a repository - GitHub Docs . (Easier to do before cloning for the first time) 
  • Mandatory: Change the project description. On the GitHub page for your project in the About section,  the description is  "generated by GitHub Classroom". Change this to a better short description of your project. Change About description in GitHub
  • Mandatory: Lock the main branch as explained in the second part of the lab, and lock the master branch (do not forget to click on including administrator)
  • Mandatory: Create a GitHub Project Board, a Trello Board, or JIIRA. Add all team members and also invite your TA. Include a link to your project board in the How to Build section of README.md 

Part  II - Scrum pre-game planning, update, and expand the project proposal

  • Create or update the following analysis documents: 
    • Project proposal updated to include new ideas, insights, or feedback from all team members (you can change nearly everything from the initial proposal).
    • Vision statement (Refer to Lecture 12 - Software Development Process Modeling.pptx). 
    • Five personas (for a team of five) (Refer to Lecture 12 - Software Development Process Modeling.pptx). 
  • On your project board 
    • Create four initial columns: Backlog,  Sprint 1 Todo,  In Progress, Done.
    • Populate the Backlog column with all the user features from the feature list. (Refer to Lecture 12 - Software Development Process Modeling.pptx). 
  • Code. Create your first release:
    • Create a proof of concept. Ensure every team member has contributed even if minimal (enough to prove each can edit, build, run, and push changes). The commit log should show contributions from all team members merged into the main branch.  
    • Produce an installable binary (or web link for web app). Weekly demos should NOT be run from an IDE. 
    • Use  git tag  or use the GitHub web interface to create a Release on GitHub
  • Update the file README.md for your project. This first page should include at least the following: 
    • A short description of your project
    • Installation instructions
    • How to build instructions. 

What to submit?

  • In this Canvas assignment: a single document with the usual template containing: (Due before next lab)
    • Updated project proposal
    • Product Vision
    • Personas
    • Initial list of user features 
  • In the git repository: (Due before the end of today's lab)
    • Updated Readme.MD with working instructions on how to run and build your project
    • One pull request from each member merged to the main branch. (Proving all members can edit, build, run, commit, and push changes) 
    • One new release available to try
  • On the project board: (Due before the end of today's lab) 
    • First column: Backlog contains all the features identified for your project (you can change it before the next lab, this does not have to be final)
    • Columns: Sprint 1 Todo, In progress, and Done are updated and reflect the current state of the project. 

Demo

  • In the lab, the TA will act as a scrum master, ensuring the meeting starts on time, every team member talks when needed, all subjects and questions are covered appropriately, and the meeting finishes on time.
    1. Every team member answers three questions while presenting the project board:
      • What have you accomplished since the last meeting? (in today's case, the last meeting is when you started discussing the project)
      • What are you working on until the next meeting?
      • What is getting in your way or keeping you from doing your job or are there any roadblocks?
    2. Anyone of the team members answers, What made you choose this project over other projects.
    3. Demo of new accomplishments (when demoing working code,  no IDE is allowed or it is considered not a finished feature.) 
      • Git repository with the sample code (Proof of Concept)
name: Project Scrum Pregame

description:
The goal for this sprint: Release the first functionality and document the architecture

At the end of this sprint: (i.e., Next lab)

  • A new release is visible in the GitHub Release
  • A UML diagram is available to help new programmers understand the architecture of your project.
    • You NEED to include a use-case diagram and a choice of Sequence, Class diagram, or both.
    • All existing classes classes should be represented. (if including class diagram)
    • Important classes to be implemented later should be represented too.
    • The diagram should be accompanied by text describing what is represented on the diagram.
    • The text should be a walkthrough as if you were explaining the important things about your project to a colleague that does not understand UML well and is new to your project.
  • Update Vision and Personas with feedback given if needed.   
  • A new Project Progress section in your project report with
    • Product Backlog: Project Backlog items (product features visible to the users. 
    • Spring Backlog: The goal of this sprint (identify what functionality you are working on)
    • List the tasks from GitHub Project (or Trello or JIIRA)  that were part of the sprint with the name of each team member who has worked on it. 
    • Note: Every week each team member should have contributed to at least one task consisting of writing code and/or one task of writing or reviewing texts or diagrams.  

Use this template for the report: (As a reference, Document Template_S25.docx  is the full template including additional sections.)

Demo

The TA will not conduct the meeting as a scrum master. Your team will select a different scrum master every week. The Scrum master is responsible for conducting the meeting, following Scrum rules including starting the meeting on time (check schedule with TA), and making sure that everybody participates. All team members need to be present. The professor/TA will act as stakeholders watching the meeting only. The Scrum master is responsible for keeping the meeting shorter than 15 minutes. 

  • Every team member (including the scrum master) answers three questions while presenting the project board:
    • What have you accomplished since the last meeting?
    • What are you working on until the next meeting?
    • What is getting in your way or keeping you from doing your job?
  • Demo of new accomplishments (working code or completed documents) 

What to submit?

  • Update your project report. It should now have the sections:
    • Project Proposal
    • Project Design
      • Vision
      • Personas 
      • Class Diagram, Sequence diagram, or both
      • Use Case diagram
    • Project Progress
      • Week 2
name: Weekly Scrum / Scrum Review Meeting - 1

description:
1. Finalize your User Stories for Sprint 2 and update the tasks in your project board's Sprint 2 Todo section.
  2. Present your Sprint goal to the professor before the end of the class to get points.

Note: No changes should be made to the Sprint 2 ToDo section of the project board after today!
name: Sprint 2 Goal

Quiz 1 - Software Engineering, Tools and Environment and Software Verification

description:
There are 3 programs in the document below. Please read through it and draw a sequence diagram for each of them.

This is a practice run for your midterm. The grade is for participation and not for correctness. You will be given the solution later.

 Sequence Diagram Exercise.pdf
name: Sequence Diagram Activity - Midterm Practice
